pros: The only positive I can provide for this workplace is the salary.

job_title: Case Manager in Bullhead City, AZ
pros: Able to help many people
cons: It's hard when client's don't want help

pros: Co workers are professional and intelligent
cons: Facility is old and run down

pros: The receptionist will bully you
cons: I worked in the Renton location. Toxic. They bully you. Talk about you. Lie will tell you not to say a word bad about the company. That one day they will see is somewhere else. And once they do the same. Basically be quiet. No breaks no lunch. Lies about your schedule when you get fired. It’s a puppy mill. They just give out pain meds they only only work with attorneys. So it’s car accidents they chase car accidents. It’s all law suits for pay out. They will lie so extremely about you when you leave it’s disturbing. Warning is all I can say

pros:
It’s a paycheck.

I have learned a lot for my next job: what I won’t accept from my future employers and to get everything in writing.

I made friends of coworkers in the trenches with me.
cons:
Often promised better- increases in pay and/or title, promoting from within, more staff to help support the clinic, training… never delivered. Massive turnover rate from burnout and underpaying good/qualified staff to keep them. 

Management is hired through nepotism over experience or any leadership skills.

Unrealistic workload (most support staff do the work of at LEAST two) that is expected, not paid it’s value, and many tasks re-tasked to others outside of their roles or certifications. Criticized for not doing things within a certain timeframe despite large workload/unrealistic goals and expectations. Little to no support offered to help meet those goals.

Terrible communication. (Sometimes after hours) Erratic last minute changes to schedule (communicated a week at a time) including being sent to alternate locations, asked (if you’re lucky, told if you’re not) to work weekends, stay late for “mandatory” staff meetings, and attempts to take back approved PTO- often with less than 24hrs notice to accommodate (constant) understaffing and whims or poor planning from management.

Never entirely or properly trained but reprimanded for not doing things the company way, disciplined/documented for mistakes. Unless you’re a provider (sometimes even then) expect to be the scapegoat whenever things go wrong.

Management trash talks former AND current employees behind their backs WITH their coworkers. Sometimes in earshot of patients.

Statements made by management about “owning” support staff and that they are all replaceable. Only the provider(s) matter. But “we’re a team.”

Always understaffed. Don’t expect consistent breaks or meals.

Terrible benefits. The monthly insurance cost is too high for almost all but the highest members of staff to afford, let alone the astronomical deductible. When a fellow employee asked the visiting rep about possible emergencies room trips with the company policy, their advice was “don’t have any”. Yikes.

So much gaslighting. No ownership on the part of management for their role in current state of clinic and staff/morale.

review_title: A Wonderful Company to Work For
pros:
- WestCare, overall, has a wonderful company culture--especially at the Foundation level
- The HR team are truly dedicated to the company and its employees. They truly make every decision with others in mind
- Phenomenal Leadership dedicated to the company’s mission, at both the regional and executive levels
- A strong emphasis on ethics, from the top down
- HR and senior leadership are dedicated to creating and maintaining a positive work environment across the board
- Growth opportunity is phenomenal--during my 2 years there I personally saw numerous people promoted into leadership roles
cons:
- WestCare is a nonprofit, so pay rates are often lower than in for-profit companies
- Many roles within WestCare are grant-based, meaning if a contract or program ends, some employees could loose their position
- WestCare can be slow or reluctant to embrace change, especially when it comes to new ways of doing things

pros: Great staff, great clients, you get to meet your clients at your own pace.

pros: Our team is awesome!  Love being involved with an organization that is changing others lives for the better.  This company has a tremendous impact each and every day with the sole mission of helping others.  Very good benefits that align with the company's culture.  They value taking care of their employees just as much as serving their client base.  The Westcare "Family", despite sounding cliche, is a reality and can be felt within the organization and its team members.  The work is challenging and also goals are obtainable resulting in a work satisfaction and growth of your talent.  I am able to surround myself with like minded people who are intelligent, understanding, and allow me to also become better at what I do.
cons: None that would deter anyone from working here or that is atypical of non-profit employment.  No company is perfect and Westcare, to me, is a hidden gem of an employer where opportunities are limited only by your work ethic and desire to make contributions to the team and organization as a whole.

job_title: Clinical Quality Improvement Specialist (CQIS) in Pacific, WA
pros: Friendly environment, flexible Work hours
cons:
Grant cycle - term , some
Training conducted in States side time

review_title: Worst work experience of my life
pros: Some of the staff members were very nice.   That included peers and upper management.  Opportunities for employment are many.
cons: Some of the staff members were horrible.  Clicks abound.   People are out to damage others in any way possible.  Lots of gossip and back-biting.  Lies.  Envy.  Soap-opera type environment.  Aside from that, some of those in management are bullies.  They watch you like a bad child and have no respect for your qualifications, education, or ability.  Intimidation is rampant.  They hire people on "temporary" status and never make them permanent.  Ignore genuine complaints from employees and requests for assistance.  People quit and are fired non-stop.  Turn over is very high.  No incentives.  Overwork is the norm.  Rigid rules are enforced for some, and totally non-existent for others.   You are fired mercilessly.  Unsanitary conditions in facilities.  Overload of cases and disorganized, archaic system of records.   Manager/supervisor makes derogatory and insulting remarks.  Ass-kissing will get you results.   Atmosphere of mistrust.  Treat employees and clients like bad children.  Does not serve and uplift.  On the contrary.

pros: Co-Workers are cool to work with
cons: No support nor backup when needed

pros: Learn new skills, work directly with clients, most people who work there truly care about their clients, flexible work schedule, locations all over the US, get to meet some amazing people, truly make a difference in people's lives. Quite a few of the Senior Management are fabulous people and will do their best to support you.
cons: No raises; training is sub-par (need training for all staff, not just for a few Counselors); salaries are way below average; never enough staff to cover all the jobs - so many are doing 2-3 jobs at once; either not given the tools necessary to complete job or it takes months of asking to get it, outdated technology; constant turn over rate means lack of stability, burn out rate very high.

pros: A lot of opportunity for movement in different states, departments, and programs.
cons:
WestCare has unfortunately grown too large, too fast. It continues to try to operate as a small, grassroots nonprofit, when it is in fact ten times that size. There is extremely high turnover as there is a huge deficiency in training. Many times, management has waited so long to fill the position that new employees get "thrown in" with little to no direction from their supervisors. 

Additionally, employees are put into management positions without leadership training. It's no wonder managers struggle to support their teams as they have not been properly trained on "what support looks like." As a result, there is a high level of fear in staff and lower management. Staff members are fearful of making the wrong decision and being ridiculed as a result.

review_title: Rewarding ;yet stressful due to who you work with.
job_title: Non Certified Substance Abuse Counselor in Chicago, IL
pros: Getting experience, helping the clients turn their lives around, don't have to bring a lunch if you like the free state food.
cons: Salary for what you do and for whom, you're not just a counselor you're a correctional officer too, and if you're a person of color you will be a token for where they need you to clean up what your Caucasian peers caused in a building due to lack of cultural diversity training, empathy, or plain old racist beliefs . Also it's too far, if you don't live close for the stress of not the inmates but coworkers.

review_title: Poor management skills, Horrible HR representative,  and no back up
pros:
Working with clients and serving community 
Working with my coworkers
cons:
No pay raises 
No advancement 
Upper management changes at the drop of a dime
No back up from supervisor 
HR representative is a bully who manipulates, scares and brakes the law
Don’t pay their bills on time
Immediate supervisors are power hungry 
Being accused of stealing
Not all employees treated the same
Work way past your time “because it’s in your job description “
Too politically involved 
Non-profit that stays in the black but doesn’t share with employees 
Doesn’t understand or care about mental illness.burnout
The list goes on...run away!!

pros: LGBTQ friendly, hire those in recovery and with criminal convictions. Holiday and vacation time is good. A lot of locations to work at.
cons: Executive and upper management staff are unprofessional, have no idea what leadership is and are only concerned with their ego and pocketbook. Promotions and raises are given based on how much you suck up not on skills and experience. Employees are not respected and are yelled at, insulted and fired for no reason if they don't like you. Many leave as soon as they can find another job. Coworkers in recovery make things difficult since for them everything is last minute.

pros: Good coworkers and client are appreciative. Vacation, holiday and sick pay is generous.
cons: Work load is ridiculous. You will never see a raise. Tons of useless trainings. Management consistently promises things will get "better" but fail to back it up.

pros: The best thing about WestCare is that the senior leadership team and state-level management truly care about the work they do and their employees. Everyone I have worked with has heart and it shines thought in everything they do.  WestCare is also a diverse organization that is full of acceptance, tolerance, and hardworking individuals at every level.
cons: Because WestCare is so diverse and widespread, it can be very lonely for remote workers, or employees who are the sole practitioner of their function in a location.

pros: Working with the population that we work with is rewarding but frequently overshadowed by the lack of support from upper management.
cons: Work load is RIDICULOUS! I have worked for many non-profits this is by far the worse! Employee moral is way down and turn over is constant but that does not seem to concern upper management one bit!

review_title: Clients are the reason we're here, co-workers make it difficult to focus on central goal
job_title: Child Development Specialist in Fresno, CA
pros: Clients willing to better themselves make it worth while, Paid sick and vacation days, consistent hours, weekends off
cons: Insurance is not that great and expensive, co-workers personalities can be intense, constant gossip, inconsistent work environment - you move around a lot

pros: The pros of working with WestCare were the salaries. Unqualified and unprofessional people were making close to $70k a year.
cons: Beyond unprofessional. Certain leadership would demean and belittle their staff.  There was very little consistency with policies. Senior management would allow the staff to sexually harrass women with no repercussions. Huge disconnect with communication. Ignoring seems to be the mode of operations. Younger talent is often dismissed with the sentiment that our ideas have less value because we're young.

pros: Being able to help the clients see things in a new way was really rewarding. Some of the coworkers were really helpful.
cons: Management is out for themselves. They say they have an open door policy but they only help a select few. Anyone else is left to fend for themselves. Considering the environment we work it, one would think they would want to be there for their employees but that is far from the truth. Pay is also a huge con. You don’t get paid enough for all the additional groups you h e to facilitate and extra caseload work you have to help cover.

pros: On paper, WestCare looks good. In reality, they do not care about their employees or the participants they claim to help.
cons: If you have drive, ambition, or vision, stay away from this place. If you want to sit on your phone all day and just get paid, then this is the place for you. They reward laziness and punish ambition. They allow their supervisors to sleep with employees and then promote those employees. Not a single person in management takes responsibility and they even tell you not to take responsibility. It’s truly the most unethical workplace and not worth working there.

pros: Company does great work in the communities it operates. Very much a feel good/ rewarding job because you feel like you're helping make a positive impact to people's lives. Co-workers are a fun group of people to work with. Pay is at or above industry standards.
cons: Long hours which include working some weekends. Health benefits are good for employee but expensive when you add spouse or family coverage.

pros: I love helping people.
cons: Huge caseload, lots of work.

job_title: Mental Health Technician in Las Vegas, NV
pros: If you enjoy helping people in need and want to get paid for it, this is the place for you. Westcare is one of the very few companies in Nevada that make a positive impact on the community where it needs it most.
cons: It's never a glamorous job, but helping people in need is the greatest reward.

pros: Great coworkers and Management all are very supportive of their peers in a personal life, work environment, and with clients. There is opportunity to move through the corporate latter and all management including the Director has an open door policy.
cons: Drive is too far and weather conditions can be tricky.

review_title: Unethical, Imposible, Turn your head and do as I say or out the door policy
pros: Pay a bit higher than the average on the circuit for  substance abuse counselors
cons: Supvisivory  staff condones unprofessional behavior by lead staff including criminal acts, nepotism, bullying, and verbal abuse, and are not accountable when these are reported. Human resources is nonresponsive to reports of criminal and abusive behavior, and executive management breaches employee confidentiality. Workload is increased to an overwhelming amount with no additional staff or support....HR misleading to staff until the wire then belittles the staff member in front of the supervisor to side and smooth it under the rug

cons: Weak benefits if you include a spouse, work/life balance gets tested, pay could always be better, some political rumblings from clinical staff.

pros: There are a lot of amazing people who work at WestCare and they care very deeply for the job that they have its relaxed but they love what they do
cons: the only con i have is that its a very fast paced environment with a lot of different things going on at one time

pros: Facility staff are wonderful co-workers. Family like atmosphere. Dedicated and committed workers. Great facility manager.
cons: Salaries are far below similar facilities in this community. Last increase in salary was 3 years ago. Annual performance apprasials do not result in improved salaries. Employees not appreciated.

pros:
Making a difference in the lives of women is very important to me.
These women are trying to rebuild their lives, and become productive members of society.
The staff really care about their clients.
cons: Sometimes it is sad to hear what the women have been through.

review_title: TOO MANY FORMER CRACKHEADS AND MENTALLY ILL PEOPLE AS "MANAGERS"
pros: Flexible schedule if your manager isnt a lonely depressed psycho cat lady
cons: work, life balance pretty bad, company penny pinches like crazy, low pay despite being in an expensive metopolitan area, no raises unless you are upper management

pros: Starting Salary is fair. The clients benefit from the therapy. The program in place detours client from failure to success
cons: Unorganized and communication between offices is zero.  If you aren’t part of the click you become a target. Counselors tend to look for the negatives of the client vs the positives.

pros: A few dedicated, talented counselors.
cons: Poor benefits.  Upper management is extremely unprofessional and accept no accountability for how poorly the program is run. Make you work hard, not smart. Directives make no sense. Idea are not welcomed. Never address low employee morale and high turn over. No support. Lots of favoritism. Upward mobility is based on who you know and not skill, ability and knowledge.

pros: Good program. Counselors were great.
cons: Coworkers were very unprofessional. A lot of gossiping about each other, slamming of office doors, and no unity. When brought to management, it wasn't an important issue to deal with. HR Rep was of no help. When Director and supervisor were out of town, office staff ran amok and singled out new employees. A lot of power trips.

pros: Pay scale is a litte more than the general rate, hires people who have formerly been incarcerated, pays for select staff to attend training
cons: Executive  staff condones unprofessional behavior by lead staff including criminal acts, nepotism, bullying, and verbal abuse, and are not accountable when these are reported. Human resources is nonresponsive to reports of criminal and abusive behavior, and executive management breaches employee confidentiality.  Workload is increased to an overwhelming amount with no additional staff or support..

pros: Boss worked in another office on the otherside of town. I was able to leave early if needed as long as work was complete.
cons: No support from upper management and was expected to implement procedures and policies. There was too much segregation between mgt and employees.

pros: Love working with people in the Dependency program and feeling like you're putting families back together again is great!
cons:
There is no where to move up in the company. 
They do not give pay raises out to anyone that's not in a managerial position.

job_title: Substance Abuse Counselor in Sheridan, IL

cons: mangement staff is poor. They don't care about direct care staff. Pay is terrible. Benefits are terrible. Most staff are more corrupt than the inmates we are working with.

pros: Clients are very great full for a empathetic counselor
cons: Very disorganized and high turnover of therapists. It seems that it does not matter what you know rather, who you know (nepotism)

job_title: Substance Abuse Counselor in York, PA

pros: Good employment opportunities. Upper-management great.

Feels like a prison.

review_title: Easy job, a lot of cliques
